text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revisions to IRM 13.1.22, Taxpayer Advocate Service, Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures, Manual Inventory Balancing Procedures.
Editorial, formatting, and grammar were made throughout the document. IPU

Inventory using National Inventory Balancing. IRM

IRM
, updated New Hire and OJI level of availability percentages using the Zip Code Field of the TAMIS Employee Screen. IRM

IRM
, updated links to the Spanish Partnership Chart, and added Spanish Partnership Office information to the Zip Code Routing Tool. IRM
, updated Intake Adjustments to weekly instead of quarterly, removed link to Intake Time Adjustment Chart since adjustment is calculated weekly as part of N-WLB calculations. ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
Editorial, formatting, and grammar were made throughout the document.

IPU 20U0408 issued 03-11-2020 IRM 13.1.22.7.1, Added new section to reinstate guidance from IGM TAS-13-0519-0008, Interim Guidance on the time requirements for transferring a case received via the TAS AMS Centralized e-911 Inventory using National Inventory Balancing.
13.1.22.6, clariﬁed new TAMIS receipts, and updated various IRM references.
IRM 13.1.22.10.2, updated Intake Adjustments to weekly instead of quarterly, removed link to Time Adjustment Chart since adjustment is calculated weekly as part of N-WLB calculations.
ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM supersedes IRM 13.1.22, Taxpayer Advocate Service, Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures, Manual Inventory Balancing Procedures dated October 29, 2019. IRM Procedural Update (IPU) 20U0371 issued on 03/11/2022 to re-validate IPU 22U0408 issued 03/11/2020 is incorporated into this IRM.
Table of Contents
Balancing Procedures
) Purpose. This section provides the procedures for the transfer of work for workload balancing purposes. and (
) Audience. These procedures apply to TAS Case Advocacy employees mining when to transfer a case for workload balancing purposes. (
) Policy Owner. The Executive Director Case Advocacy, Intake & Technical Support (EDCA-ITS), who is under the Deputy National Taxpayer (DNTA). (
) Program Owner. The Executive Director Case Advocacy (EDCA), who is the DNTA. (
) To balance workload across the TAS organization, a national workload balancing (N-WLB) system was instituted on May
) Pursuant to IRC §
(c), the Office of the Taxpayer Advocate (known as Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS)) shall assist taxpayers to resolve with the IRS. (

) The N-WLB Coordinator is responsible for managing the national workload balancing program, providing guidance to the Local Taxpayer Advocate offices, and determining when it is appropriate to transfer cases using balancing procedures. The N-WLB Coordinator reports to the EDCA-ITS. (
) TAS case advocacy employees are responsible for completing the TAMIS transfer procedures. (
) Case Advocacy managers are responsible for making case assignments ensuring employees within their purview are following the workload procedures contained in this IRM. (

) Reports to monitor the appropriate and timely routing of TAS cases using workload balancing procedures are derived from Taxpayer Advocate ment Information System (TAMIS) and the Case Quality Review System (CQRS). a. The CQRS generates monthly and ﬁscal year cumulative reports as as speciﬁc queries for data analysis. b. TAS uses Business Objects Enterprise (BOE) to generate reports to monitor office inventory levels and case transfers. (
) The following table contains a list of terms used throughout this IRM. Term Deﬁnition Active Status When a case advocate (CA) or bilingual case advocate (BCA) is available to accept cases. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Manual Inventory Balancing Procedures
Audience. These procedures apply to TAS Case Advocacy employees mining when to transfer a case for workload balancing purposes.
Policy Owner. The Executive Director Case Advocacy, Intake & Technical Support (EDCA-ITS), who is under the Deputy National Taxpayer
To balance workload across the TAS organization, a national workload balancing (N-WLB) system was instituted on May 5, 2006.
Pursuant to IRC § 7803(c), the Office of the Taxpayer Advocate (known as the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS)) shall assist taxpayers to resolve problems

The N-WLB Coordinator is responsible for managing the national workload balancing program, providing guidance to the Local Taxpayer Advocate (LTA) offices, and determining when it is appropriate to transfer cases using workload balancing procedures. The N-WLB Coordinator reports to the EDCA-ITS.
The following table contains a list of terms used throughout this

Inventory Balancing Procedures 13.1.22 page 3 Term Deﬁnition Spanish Case Any cases where the taxpayer speaks Spanish and all contact with the taxpayer is in Spanish, or the taxpayer and the POA speaks Spanish, or the taxpayer speaks Spanish and the POA speaks English and the box in line 2 of Form 2848 is not checked. Taxpayer Advocate Received The date TAS received the tax- Date payer’s inquiry. Transfer Guidelines A set of guidelines listing where TAS will route a case that has a speciﬁc issue identiﬁed by the guidelines. Zip Code Routing The tool used by TAS to identify by zip code where the case will be worked.
Manual Inventory Balancing Procedures

) These procedures apply to the transfer of work for workload purposes only. The rules outlined here apply to both English and cases. (

) types of cases; English and a. An English case is deﬁned as any case where:

) Each Monday morning, the N-WLB coordinator will generate a series of to determine the offices involved in N-WLB through the following Friday. (
) Using the deﬁnitions in IRM

, the inventory for each office is down to show Spanish and English open inventory. Open inventory includes cases assigned to a CA or BCA in active status, and: a. All cases with a status not equal to C (closed); b. Criteria codes
; c. All TAS assigned Congressional cases; d. All regular and reopened cases; and e.
percent of cases identiﬁed as Bulk. See IRM
, Bulk Receipts for the deﬁnition of a bulk case. (
) The number of available CAs and BCAs is determined on Monday morning. Available CAs and BCAs are those in active status on the (TAMIS). (

) Adjustments are made automatically to the active CA/BCA counts for: a. Permanent part-time employees (CA/BCA); b. Small offices (offices with less than ﬁve CAs); c. Time spent by non-Intake Advocates (IA) performing intake work; and d. New hires and on-the-job instructors (OJI) on partial availability. See
, Accounting for a New Hire and OJI. (
) From these reports, the following information is calculated: a. Each office’s average English inventory per CA. This is determined by the open English inventory as deﬁned in IRM
, Introduction, divided by the number of active non-BCAs. b. Each office’s average Spanish inventory per BCA. This is determined the open Spanish inventory as deﬁned in IRM
, divided by number of active BCAs. c. The national average English inventory per CA. This is determined by open English inventory as deﬁned in IRM
, divided by the number of active non-BCAs. d. The national average Spanish inventory per BCA. This is determined the open Spanish inventory as deﬁned in IRM
, divided by number of active BCAs.
Each Monday morning, the N-WLB coordinator will generate a series of reports to determine the offices involved in N-WLB through the following Friday.
(08-04-2022) TAS National Office Responsibilities
The number of available CAs and BCAs is determined on Monday morning. Available CAs and BCAs are those in active status on the (TAMIS).
a. Each office’s average English inventory per CA. This is determined by the open English inventory as deﬁned in IRM
, Introduction, divided by the number of active non-BCAs. b. Each office’s average Spanish inventory per BCA. This is determined the open Spanish inventory as deﬁned in IRM
, divided by the number of active BCAs. c. The national average English inventory per CA. This is determined by open English inventory as deﬁned in IRM
, divided by the number of active non-BCAs. d. The national average Spanish inventory per BCA. This is determined by the open Spanish inventory as deﬁned in IRM
, divided by the number of active BCAs.
Taxpayer Advocate Case (

) The following conditions are used to determine an office’s eligibility to receive or send cases for English or Spanish N-WLB, and the number of cases they are eligible to receive on both a daily and weekly basis (English and Spanish eligibility are determined separately): a. The standard to compare offices’ inventories is the national average inventory per CA/BCA. b. Any office with plus or minus (+/-) ﬁve cases from the national average eligible to send or receive cases, respectively. c. The maximum number of cases a receiving office is eligible to receive is one case per active CA/BCA per day. (
) Each LTA office will have two designated recipients for N-WLB email messages. (

) Once the N-WLB determinations are made, all inventory balancing coordina- tors will receive an email providing the English and Spanish national and a summary of the English and Spanish transfers for the time period covered. Note: An office may send cases to, or receive cases from, more than one office. (
) It is the responsibility of the LTA offices to appropriately apply the deferral rules. (
) When a CA/BCA will be out of the office for one week or more (i.e., seven or more consecutive calendar days) but less than

calendar days, the Inactive Indicator ﬁeld on the TAMIS Employee Screen must be changed to deferral by close of business (COB) the workday prior to the CA/BCA’s scheduled departure. Examples include: a. CA/BCA is on extended leave (including annual and sick leave); b. A detail outside of TAS; or, c. On non-casework assignment (e.g., full-time NTEU/EEO). Note: Deferral status does not require reassignment of the CA/BCA inventory. However, if the CA/BCA will be out of the office for more than
calendar days, his or her open inventory must be reassigned and the employee’s status on TAMIS should be changed to inactive. (

) Documentation (e.g., e-mail) including dates, is required for non-casework as- signments and must be sent to the headquarters’ N-WLB coordinator, through the area coordinator, by COB the day the CA/BCA is to be placed in deferral status. If the work assignment is for a national project, the documentation come from the office responsible for the project (e.g., Employee Support and Development (ESD) for training assignments, EDCA for case project assign- ments, etc.) (
) By COB one workday prior to the return of the CA/BCA, change the Inactive Indicator ﬁeld on the TAMIS Employee Screen to active status. (
) If a CA/BCA is retiring or permanently leaving the CA/BCA position, the employee may be placed in deferral status
calendar days prior to the scheduled departure date. (
) Offices may not place a CA/BCA used as an IA in deferral status. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
H

) The following conditions are used to determine an office’s eligibility to receive or send cases for English or Spanish N-WLB, and the number of cases they are eligible to receive on both a daily and weekly basis (English and Spanish eligibility are determined separately): a. The standard to compare offices’ inventories is the national average inventory per CA/BCA. b. Any office with plus or minus (+/-) ﬁve cases from the national average eligible to send or receive cases, respectively. c. The maximum number of cases a receiving office is eligible to receive is one case per active CA/BCA per day. (
) Each LTA office will have two designated recipients for N-WLB email messages. (

) Once the N-WLB determinations are made, all inventory balancing coordina- tors will receive an email providing the English and Spanish national averages and a summary of the English and Spanish transfers for the time period covered.
Note: An office may send cases to, or receive cases from, more than one office.

It is the responsibility of the LTA offices to appropriately apply the deferral rules. When a CA/BCA will be out of the office for one week or more (i.e., seven more consecutive calendar days) but less than

calendar days, the Inactive Indicator ﬁeld on the TAMIS Employee Screen must be changed to deferral by close of business (COB) the workday prior to the CA/BCA’s scheduled departure. Examples include: a. CA/BCA is on extended leave (including annual and sick leave); b. A detail outside of TAS; or, c. On non-casework assignment (e.g., full-time NTEU/EEO). Deferral status does not require reassignment of the CA/BCA inventory. However, if the CA/BCA will be out of the office for more than

days, his or her open inventory must be reassigned and the employee’s status on TAMIS should be changed to inactive. Documentation (e.g., e-mail) including dates, is required for non-casework signments and must be sent to the headquarters’ N-WLB coordinator, the area coordinator, by COB the day the CA/BCA is to be placed in status. If the work assignment is for a national project, the documentation come from the office responsible for the project (e.g., Employee Support Development (ESD) for training assignments, EDCA for case project ments, etc.) By COB one workday prior to the return of the CA/BCA, change the Indicator ﬁeld on the TAMIS Employee Screen to active status. If a CA/BCA is retiring or permanently leaving the CA/BCA position, the employee may be placed in deferral status
calendar days prior to the scheduled departure date. Offices may not place a CA/BCA used as an IA in deferral status. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) The same deferral rules and procedures apply for an IA. (
) The intake time adjustment is adjusted to account for an IA in deferral The office must advise the N-WLB Coordinator of the deferral. See IRM

) It is the responsibility of each local and Area office to ensure the zip code is updated no later than the day before the next training phase begins. (

) The following type of case is eligible for N-WLB: a. New receipt – An English or Spanish case received after an office on Monday morning of each week, or a case received on the Friday not loaded on TAMIS; Note: A case received and loaded to TAMIS anytime on Friday, but assigned to a CA/BCA is counted in open inventory and is not eligible for N-WLB the following Monday. b. Non-ﬁlers meeting the new receipt deﬁnition in (a) above; c. Correspondence speciﬁcally addressed to a LTA office; and,
Manual Inventory Balancing Procedures 13.1.22
It is the responsibility of each local and Area office to ensure the zip code ﬁeld is updated no later than the day before the next training phase begins.
Taxpayer Advocate Case d. Correspondence addressed to the LTA. Note: Follow procedures in
), TAS Transfer Time Frames and Initial Contact Require- ments for those cases where the taxpayer has contacted the office or LTA directly. (

) Cases not eligible for N-WLB are: a. Cases meeting transfer criteria per the TAS Case Transfer Guidelines; b. TAS Congressional cases; c. Cases originating from the National Taxpayer Advocate’s (NTA’s) office; d. Senate Finance Committee (SFC) cases; e. Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act (SBREFA) f. Reopened cases; g. Cases meeting the Bulk deﬁnition. See IRM
, Bulk h. Cases identiﬁed on TAMIS as e-Trak; i. Cases referred from a Low Income Tax Clinic (LITC); and j. Schemes. (

) N-WLB is for cases remaining in an office after applying transfer criteria and Zip Code routing. Before transferring a case for N-WLB: a. First apply TAS Case Transfer Guidelines, b. If there is no transfer criteria, second apply Zip Code routing. (

) If a sending office cannot meet its daily allotment of cases, it may review receipts and transfers-in for one of the issues listed below. Only these issues are allowed as an exception to the transfer guidelines for N-WLB purposes, and only if an office cannot meet its daily allotment of cases to transfer. This exception only applies to offices eligible to transfer out work under N-WLB. • FUTA – Open • FUTA – Closed (

) A case should not be transferred multiple times. This is generally not in the taxpayer’s best interest. A case transferred to balance inventories should be transferred again. When working with the taxpayer, TAS can improve taxpayer’s experience with the IRS by working expeditiously with the Case transfers should be transparent to the taxpayer, i.e., the taxpayer not notice a delay. For some situations, any delay by TAS could mean TAS unable to grant relief. (
) Use TAMIS transfer reason code
(zero) when transferring a case for N-WLB. This transfer reason code (TRC) is only used when transferring a for N-WLB. (
) Area balancing is only allowed for egregious situations and must be coordi- nated in advance with both the EDCA-ITS inventory analyst and the N-WLB coordinator. (

) Advance knowledge of events requiring new receipts to be re-routed is ered when determining the volume of cases a site can receive. These may include: training events, office moves, Tax Forums, etc.

(zero) when transferring a case for N-WLB. This transfer reason code (TRC) is only used when transferring a case for N-WLB. (

) All cases must be transferred within one workday from the Taxpayer Received Date (TARD). Sending the case timely is essential, especially time-sensitive issues, when working with the taxpayer, TAS can improve taxpayer’s experience with the IRS by working expeditiously with the Case transfers should be transparent to the taxpayer, i.e., the taxpayer not notice a delay. For some situations, any delay by TAS could mean TAS unable to grant relief. (
) The daily transfer deadline is as follows: • Monday –
p.m. local time of the transferring office. • Tuesday through Friday –
p.m. local time of the transferring Exception: If a federally observed holiday falls on Monday,
Exception: If a federally observed holiday falls on Monday, transfers are allowed until 3 p.m. local time on the subsequent day.
Example: If an office can transfer ﬁve cases per day but only transfers two on a given day, the office cannot send eight cases the next day.
) Use the ﬁrst in/ﬁrst out method for selecting a case for N-WLB. (
) On the TAMIS inventory screen, cases are listed in criteria code order. To select a case, use a sequential order by case ﬁle number. (
) If an office is sending cases to more than one office, alternate the offices to avoid overloading one particular office. (
) For TAS cases received via the Centralized Area AMS queues, the time required has been modiﬁed to one workday from the date the case was loaded from AMS into TAMIS. (

) This change is designed to prevent taxpayers’ cases from being multiple times, which causes delays in resolving the taxpayers’ issues. delays can sometimes prevent TAS from providing relief. In addition, tious resolution of the taxpayers’ problems can improve their experience the IRS. (
) TAMIS is programed to ensure the requirements in IRM

, TAS Transfer Time Frames and Initial Contact Requirements, are followed; prevent cases being transferred on or after the Initial Contact Date is this programming prevents a transfer, TAS employees must not change TARD or otherwise manipulate the data in TAMIS to transfer the case. take the following actions to transfer the case: a. The Transferring Office will send an email to tas.inventory@irs.gov including the TAMIS case ﬁle number and the ORG number of the Receiving Office. b. EDCA-ITS employees with authority to bypass the transfer TAMIS will transfer the case to the Receiving Office. They will also **TRANSFER** into the TAMIS History. c. The Receiving Office is required to complete the Initial Contact per
, Initial Contact Completed by Case Advocates. The ments regarding contacting the taxpayer prior to transfer in IRM are suspended, as the contact will be performed by the receiving

The Transferring Office will send an email to tas.inventory@irs.gov including the TAMIS case ﬁle number and the ORG number of the Receiving Office. EDCA-ITS employees with authority to bypass the transfer restriction in TAMIS will transfer the case to the Receiving Office. They will also input **TRANSFER** into the TAMIS History. The Receiving Office is required to complete the Initial Contact per IRM
, Initial Contact Completed by Case Advocates. The require- ments regarding contacting the taxpayer prior to transfer in IRM are suspended, as the contact will be performed by the receiving office.

) The following sections outline various adjustments to the case advocate under N-WLB. to Case Count (

) Any changes to a part-time schedule must be communicated to the Advocates ters’ N-WLB coordinator. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Manual Inventory Balancing Procedures
) A reduction to the active CA/BCA count is made by the headquarters’ coordinator to recognize intake activities performed in the office. Time Adjustment (
) The adjustment is based on the percentage of time spent performing intake work during the prior week, and is modiﬁed weekly. (
) An office’s intake adjustment will be reduced, but not below zero, by the
A reduction to the active CA/BCA count is made by the headquarters’ N-WLB coordinator to recognize intake activities performed in the office.
Example: An office with a computed intake time adjustment of 1.25 has one IA. The office receives an intake time adjustment of .25.

An office must notify the headquarters’ N-WLB coordinator of changes to staffing. A small office is deﬁned as one having no TAGM or analyst, and ﬁve or case advocates. A CA/BCA in a smaller office is more likely to perform ancillary duties than case work (e.g., participating in Outreach events). These offices are less able to absorb unanticipated absences and time spent performing casework duties. To address the unique challenges of a smaller office, they are allowed a ﬁcation to the intake time adjustment. This modiﬁcation is equal to the greater of the current intake time or
percent for each on-role CA/BCA, up to a maximum of one.
This modiﬁcation is equal to the greater of the current intake time adjustment or 20 percent for each on-role CA/BCA, up to a maximum of one.
Note: The 20 percent reduction is based on average indirect time.

Office A has a LTA and three CAs. Their computed intake time adjust- ment is .50. Since this office meets the small office deﬁnition, their intake time adjustment is .60, the greater of the computed adjustment of .50 or 3 (the number of CAs) multiplied by 20 percent.
